issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw: If you want to change a model, you'll have to publish a `model.proto` message to the `~/model/modify` topic. There is a chunk of code missing in [Link.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6977194dfe4b0412c365cc439c7c91c2452cfba3/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default#cl-842) that should process visual information.
content.html: If you want to change a model, you'll have to publish a model.proto message to the ~/model/modify topic. There is a chunk of code missing in Link.cc that should process visual information.

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Dear Nathan, if I understand correctly your answer there is currently no way to retrieve the actual color of a visual if it has changed before the new client connects to gzserver. And this is so because updates are missing in Link.cc. Am I right?

This is also my feeling that such updates are missing (no actual change for visuals_M ever happens). And I was considering, as a possible fix, a subscription to the ~/visual topic in World::Load() with an appropriate callback. This would avoid the use of the ~/model/modify topic and let model/link updates ignore visual as they currently do. 

But there is something that worries me and seems to be a concern for the authors of gazebo/physics: several comments indicate that visual updates  shouldn't be managed from within the physics namespace (see e.g., Link.cc at line 1036).

So what should be the ultimate fix: a visual plugin based on the rendering?
Best regards,
Luc
content.html:
Dear Nathan, if I understand correctly your answer there is currently no way to retrieve the actual color of a visual if it has changed before the new client connects to gzserver. And this is so because updates are missing in Link.cc. Am I right?

This is also my feeling that such updates are missing (no actual change for visuals_M ever happens). And I was considering, as a possible fix, a subscription to the ~/visual topic in World::Load() with an appropriate callback. This would avoid the use of the ~/model/modify topic and let model/link updates ignore visual as they currently do.

But there is something that worries me and seems to be a concern for the authors of gazebo/physics: several comments indicate that visual updates shouldn't be managed from within the physics namespace (see e.g., Link.cc at line 1036).

So what should be the ultimate fix: a visual plugin based on the rendering? Best regards, Luc

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Issue #1567 was related, in that changes in model scale weren't persistent between gzclient instances. This is being fixed on 4.1 in pull request #1597 and may provide some clues about how to ensure other properties are persistent.

cc @iche033
content.html:
Issue #1567 was related, in that changes in model scale weren't persistent between gzclient instances. This is being fixed on 4.1 in pull request #1597 and may provide some clues about how to ensure other properties are persistent.

cc @iche033

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Correct: There is no way to retrieve visual information that has been dynamically changed via the `~/visual` topic. The server (`gzserver`) is the persistent process, and it currently does not store changes to visual information.

It would be better to use `~/model/modify` for any changes that should persist between client instances. The `~/visual` topic would then handle any visual-only changes that do not need to persist between client instances. 

You can safely ignore the comment at Link.cc:1036.

The ultimate fix would occur in Link.cc in the `::ProcessMsg` function. This function needs to be extended to process visuals.
content.html:
Correct: There is no way to retrieve visual information that has been dynamically changed via the ~/visual topic. The server (gzserver) is the persistent process, and it currently does not store changes to visual information.

It would be better to use ~/model/modify for any changes that should persist between client instances. The ~/visual topic would then handle any visual-only changes that do not need to persist between client instances.

You can safely ignore the comment at Link.cc:1036.

The ultimate fix would occur in Link.cc in the ::ProcessMsg function. This function needs to be extended to process visuals.

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw: agreed, publish to `~/model/modify` with with new visual values and let the server inform the clients of changes - this needs to be implemented
content.html: agreed, publish to ~/model/modify with with new visual values and let the server inform the clients of changes - this needs to be implemented

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Dear Nathan, Ian, Stefan,

I've attached a possible fix for this issue as a patch against the current Gazebo trunk (revision 22830), which adds a topic ("/gazebo/VISUAL_NAME/visual_updates") to each Visual that "re-publishes" visual update messages.
A Link subscribes to this topic for each Visual it creates on instantiation, and updates the visual message entry for a Visual when an update is "re-published".

This doesn't use the "~/model/modify" topic as suggested before, but it allows new clients that connect to a running simulation to retrieve the current attributes of Visual instances via a "scene_info" request.

If it is useful/helpful, I could also add (or implement this instead) the ability to process Visual updates in "Link::ProcessMsg".

With best regards,
Fabian Aichele
content.html:
Dear Nathan, Ian, Stefan,

I've attached a possible fix for this issue as a patch against the current Gazebo trunk (revision 22830), which adds a topic ("/gazebo/VISUAL_NAME/visual_updates") to each Visual that "re-publishes" visual update messages. A Link subscribes to this topic for each Visual it creates on instantiation, and updates the visual message entry for a Visual when an update is "re-published".

This doesn't use the "~/model/modify" topic as suggested before, but it allows new clients that connect to a running simulation to retrieve the current attributes of Visual instances via a "scene_info" request.

If it is useful/helpful, I could also add (or implement this instead) the ability to process Visual updates in "Link::ProcessMsg".

With best regards, Fabian Aichele

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Thanks for the patch @faichele ; I committed it to branch `issue_1573` (cac5c9b0f232) with some style fixes.

@iche033 what do you think? He adds a publisher to `rendering::Visual`, which seems like a good place for it, but he makes a new topic based on the visual name. I think I would still prefer to use `~/model/modify`.
content.html:
Thanks for the patch @faichele ; I committed it to branch issue_1573 (cac5c9b0f232) with some style fixes.

@iche033 what do you think? He adds a publisher to rendering::Visual, which seems like a good place for it, but he makes a new topic based on the visual name. I think I would still prefer to use ~/model/modify.

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Thanks @faichele. The primary problem with your patch is the number of new publishers and subscribers that will be created. A complex robot, such as Atlas or PR2, will create a lot of new topics and introduce overhead.

Can you explain in more detail why you didn't use the `~/model/modify` topic? Is there a case where this topic does not work?
content.html:
Thanks @faichele. The primary problem with your patch is the number of new publishers and subscribers that will be created. A complex robot, such as Atlas or PR2, will create a lot of new topics and introduce overhead.

Can you explain in more detail why you didn't use the ~/model/modify topic? Is there a case where this topic does not work?

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
The main reason I added a per-visual topic was that I had already finished the main part of this mini-patch before I saw your suggestion in the comments for the reported issue.
That's why I asked if you'd prefer the cleaner solution using the "~/model/modify" topic, instead of introducing a new topic for each visual.
I'll create a simple test case for modifying visual properties via "~/model/modify" (because I didn't test that case yet), and try to prepare an alternative patch.
content.html: The main reason I added a per-visual topic was that I had already finished the main part of this mini-patch before I saw your suggestion in the comments for the reported issue. That's why I asked if you'd prefer the cleaner solution using the "~/model/modify" topic, instead of introducing a new topic for each visual. I'll create a simple test case for modifying visual properties via "~/model/modify" (because I didn't test that case yet), and try to prepare an alternative patch.

issue.title: scene_info does not reflect older changes to visuals

content.raw:
Hello!

It took a little longer than anticipated to get back to this issue, but attached above you'll find an alternative patch for persisting updates to Visual objects.
I've chosen the approach to check in Scene::Prerender() whether a model message contains visual sub-messages, and if yes, to append these to the visual messages that need to be processed.
That way, updates to visual properties can use the "~/model/modify" topic alone, as suggested after I submitted my original patch. 

Thank you!
With best regards,
Fabian Aichele
content.html:
Hello!

It took a little longer than anticipated to get back to this issue, but attached above you'll find an alternative patch for persisting updates to Visual objects. I've chosen the approach to check in Scene::Prerender() whether a model message contains visual sub-messages, and if yes, to append these to the visual messages that need to be processed. That way, updates to visual properties can use the "~/model/modify" topic alone, as suggested after I submitted my original patch.

Thank you! With best regards, Fabian Aichele
